title: Can McKinsey rediscover its mojo?
text:

McKinsey: ‘Evolve 2 Excellence' or die

What do Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg, Joe Biden's new transportation secretary Pete Buttigieg, and Google's Sundar Pichai have in common?

Apart from all likely being on first-name terms with Mark Zuckerberg, the Big Tech titans and former mayor of South Bend, Indiana, share a common superpower: “the McKinsey mystique”. 

That is to say that they hail from the secretive consulting powerhouse McKinsey, a place that seems to churn out influential alumni faster than an OxyContin production line at Purdue Pharma circa 2017.

We digress — the whole mystique concept dates back to McKinsey co-founder Marvin Bower, who laid down the principles that its partners wouldn't take on clients about whom it had a shadow of a doubt and would always “uphold absolute integrity”.

But all that's been called into question since the consultant got tangled up in the aforementioned opioid crisis, settling claims for $574m relating to its advice to Purdue, the pharmaceutical company owned by the billionaire Sackler family, which fuelled the epidemic.

McKinsey admitted no guilt in the settlement, although it expressed “regret”.

One particularly mystifying strategy advised by McKinsey during this time, the slickly-packaged “Evolve 2 Excellence” plan, was designed to “turbocharge” the company's sales of its highly addictive painkillers. 

It involved marketing tactics you'd expect from the hyper-competitive world of Big Pharma — incentivising prolific distributors, encouraging brand loyalty, offering mail-order deliveries to frequent users. Only, as part of a separate settlement with the US Department of Justice, McKinsey's client pleaded guilty to extensive criminal wrongdoing.

The debacle is the pièce de résistance in a collection of scandals inherited by McKinsey's global managing partner Kevin Sneader since he entered the top job in 2018.

Purdue agreed last October to pay more than $8bn in a criminal and civil settlement with the DoJ.

He has navigated reputational landmines across Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Russia, France and within its own ranks, while vowing to be more selective about how the firm chooses its next generation of clients.

We are about to find out how his colleagues think he has handled this laundry list of PR crises, as the FT revealed on Monday that McKinsey's 650 senior partners have begun voting on whether Sneader should serve a second term.

The triennial process, which has already selected 10 potential candidates and could narrow the list to two finalists as soon as this week, is both routine and being seen as a referendum on the 54-year-old Scot's response to McKinsey's recent travails.

Insiders told the FT it would be unusual for Sneader not to be re-elected, as his five predecessors were. But a new generation at McKinsey has the potential to tip the scale.

To take a page from Darwin, not to mention “Evolve 2 Excellence”, it's survival of the fittest out there.

Required reading: don't miss this just published McKinsey deep-dive by the FT's Andrew Edgecliffe-Johnson, Andrew Hill and Hannah Kuchler for a closer look into one of the world's most powerful companies.  

The private jet deal that lets everybody win

The last time DD checked in on Signature Aviation, a FTSE 250-listed company that provides refuelling and maintenance services for private jets, battle lines were being drawn. 

Global Infrastructure Partners, the New York-based group founded by former Credit Suisse banker Adebayo Ogunlesi, had made a £3.4bn bid that trumped an offer from Blackstone and Cascade, which manages Bill Gates' fortune.

But Signature's chair Sir Nigel Rudd was essentially encouraging rival bidders to get back into the race, and chess-like calculations were being made about how a protracted public wrangle might play out. 

Fast-forward a few weeks and the rivals are friends. Blackstone, Cascade and GIP joined forces in a fresh £3.5bn bid this month (catch up here). 

If it goes through, it will let Rudd “preserve in formaldehyde” his reputation for dealing with private equity groups, one adviser told DD (Rudd chaired Boots when it agreed a £11bn take-private deal with KKR in 2007).

The other big winners that emerge from the plan: the deal's professional advisers. Take a look at these fees, from documents published on Monday. This is for the buyers, whose advisers include UBS, Gleacher Shacklock, RBC, Kirkland & Ellis and Linklaters . . . 


. . . and this, for the sellers, whose advisers include JPMorgan, Jefferies and Slaughter and May. Signature is set to spend a cool million dollars on PR advice, which Tulchan Communications is in charge of, if the deal materialises: 

So far, it's a long way from the $1.1bn in fees racked up by the London Stock Exchange Group's takeover of data provider Refinitiv — one of the biggest paydays for a UK acquisition. 

But, for a few people, it might just bring private jet travel a little closer within reach. 

Stephan Crétier strikes out

According to people around him, Stephan Crétier is a hard-charging dealmaker who doesn't give up easily.

But the baseball-loving chief executive of GardaWorld, a Montreal-based security company backed by the private equity group BC Partners, may have to walk away from his biggest gambit yet.

GardaWorld said on Monday that it won't raise its £3.7bn hostile bid for UK-listed G4S, the world's biggest security company. Its 235p-a-share offer is trumped by a friendly 245p bid by its US-based rival Allied Universal that already has the support of the company's board. 

Crétier went public with a hostile approach in September, calling the company “deeply troubled,” describing his approach as a “rescue bid” and saying its senior management had failed to deliver. G4S had privately rebuffed him twice in the months leading up to that. 

By scorching the earth beneath him, he led G4S executives — in search of alternative options — to talk seriously with Allied. 

Though Crétier said in December that he was weighing a higher bid, it never materialised. The obvious explanation is that he couldn't participate in an auction his backers didn't want to win, writes Bryce Elder in the FT's Lombard column.

If the Allied bid goes through, he will have paved the way for a good deal for G4S shareholders — and a huge expansion by a rival group. 

Job moves

Roberto Castello Branco is set to be replaced as head of Brazilian oil producer Petrobras after being publicly criticised by the country's president Jair Bolsonaro over recent increases in the price of petrol and diesel. More here.

HSBC has reshuffled its top ranks ahead of a strategic “pivot to Asia”:

  • European operations head Nuno Matos has been promoted to global head of wealth and personal banking. He will be replaced by chief compliance officer Colin Bell.

  • Chief executive of the bank's US division Michael Roberts will expand his responsibilities to become chief executive of the US, Canada and Latin America.

  • Stephen Moss will move from London where he worked as a regional chief executive to Dubai to run the bank's Middle East, north Africa and Turkey business.

Former Bank of England governor Mark Carney has joined the board of online payments provider Stripe. More here.

Julia Schiller, former counsel to the assistant attorney-general of the US Department of Justice's antitrust division, has joined law firm O'Melveny as a partner in its antitrust and competition practice, based in Washington, DC.

Davis Polk hired Jason Xu as a partner in its corporate department in Beijing. He was previously deputy head of Chinese equity capital markets at Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer.

King & Spalding has hired Russell Sacks as a partner in its corporate finance practice. He joins the New York office from Shearman & Sterling.
